Tweet: Dhritarashtra said: O Sanjaya, assembled in the holy land of Kurukshetra and desiring to fight, what did my sons and the sons of Pandu do?
Sanjaya said: Beholding the Pandava army arrayed in battle formation, King Duryodhana then approached his teacher and spoke these words.
Behold, O teacher, this mighty army of the sons of Pandu, arrayed by the son of Drupada, your wise disciple.
Here are the brave warriors like Bhima and Arjuna fighting fiercely in battle. Yuyudhana, Virata, and Drupada are also mighty warriors.
Dhrishtaketu, Chekitana, Kashiraja, Purujit, Kuntibhoja, Shaibya are all valiant warriors.
Yudhamanyu, Vikranta, Uttamauja, the valiant; Saubhadra, the son of Draupadi; all of them are mighty warriors.
O best of the Brahmanas, know those who are our leaders in the army. I shall now tell you of them for your information.
You are Bhishma, Karna, Krpa, victorious in battle; Ashwatthama, Vikarna, and also Saumadatti.
Others too, many of them, valiant warriors, sacrificing their lives for my sake, armed with various weapons, all skilled in battle.
Our strength, protected by Bhishma, is inadequate. But their strength, protected by Bhima, is adequate.
May all of you be stationed according to your respective positions on all sides of Bhishma only.
His grandfather Kuru, filled with joy and pride, roared like a lion and blew his conch loudly, displaying his prowess.
Then, conches, drums, and horns, blaring forth simultaneously, were sounded; and the noise was tumultuous.
Then, in the great conchshell, white horses yoked, Krishna and Arjuna stationed, blew their divine conches.
The conch named Panchajanya, the bow called Hrishikesha, the sword named Devadatta, and the mace called Dhananjaya.
The king Yudhishthira, the son of Kunti, along with Nakula and Sahadeva, possessed the inexhaustible wealth of jewels and flowers.
Kashya, the Supreme among the Vasus, Shikhandi, the great charioteer, Dhristadyumna, Virata, and the unconquered Satyaki.
Draupadi, the daughter of Drupada, and all the sons of Prithivi, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadra, all blew their respective conch shells.
That sound shattered the hearts of the Dhartarashtras, and also the sky and the earth, resounding tumultuously.
Then, seeing the Kauravas arrayed in battle order, Arjuna, the son of Pandu, raising his bow, spoke these words to Krishna, O King.
Arjuna said: O infallible one, please place my chariot between the two armies so that I may see those who stand here, desiring to fight.
With what effort should one engage in this battle?
I see those who have assembled here, desiring to fight in the battle, out of love for the evil-minded son of Dhritarashtra.
Sanjaya said: O Bharata, having thus been addressed by Gudakesha, Hrishikesha placed the excellent chariot in the midst of the two armies.
Bhishma and Drona, along with all the other warriors, said: "O Partha, behold these assembled Kurus."
There Arjuna could see, stationed in both armies, fathers and grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, friends, and also fathers-in-law and friends in both armies.
Seeing all his relatives present there, Arjuna, the son of Kunti, overwhelmed by great compassion and sorrowfully spoke these words.
Arjuna said: O Krishna, seeing my own kinsmen standing arrayed, eager for battle, my limbs fail and my mouth is parched.
Trembling arises in my body, and my hair stands on end. The Gandiva bow slips from my hand, and my skin is burning all over.
I am unable to stand still; my mind is unsteady. I see adverse omens, O Keshava.
I do not see any good in killing my own kinsmen in battle, nor do I desire victory, O Krishna, nor pleasures.
What is the use of a kingdom, Govinda, or pleasures, or even life itself, to us, for whose sake the kingdom, pleasures, and joys are desired?
Those who are situated in the battlefield, having renounced their lives and wealth, include teachers, fathers, sons, and also grandfathers.
Maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, sons, grandsons, as well as other relatives, I do not wish to kill, even if they kill me, O Madhusudana.
Even by killing all these aggressors, our hearts will be satisfied, O Krishna, what joy will there be for us?
We should not kill our relatives, the sons of Dhritarashtra, who are our family members, even if they are filled with greed.
Even though these people, whose minds are overpowered by greed, do not see the fault in the destruction of families and the sin in betraying friends.
How can we not know how to dispel our sin, O Janardana, when we see the crime of destroying the family?
When the family declines, the eternal family duties perish. With the destruction of righteousness, unrighteousness becomes prevalent in the entire family.
When unrighteousness prevails, O Krishna, the women of the family become corrupt; and from the corruption of women, O descendant of Vrishni, arises unwanted progeny.
Those who destroy the family, and are impure, fall into hell. The ancestors of such people are deprived of offerings of rice and water.
By these faults of those who destroy the family, producing confusion in caste, the eternal duties of caste and family are destroyed.
For those who are born with noble qualities, O Janardana, dwelling in hell is not destined.
Oh, how terrible it is that we are determined to commit a great sin by killing our own kinsmen out of greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.
If they do not retaliate against me with weapons in battle, the sons of Dhritarashtra, then my safety will be assured.
Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus, Arjuna, in the midst of the battlefield, sat down on the seat of his chariot, casting aside bow and arrows, his mind overwhelmed with sorrow.
